abstract.p: Thomas S Kerrigan letter on Benedict Nightingale's May 7 article on resurgence of T S Elliot's play The Family reunion recalls 1959 dinner convesation with English novelist C P Snow about Elliot

block.p: Benedict Nightingale's observations about the resurgence of T. S. Eliot's verse drama ''The Family Reunion'' [''The Wintry Music of T. S. Eliot,'' May 7] made me think back to a dinner conversation I had in 1959 with the then-famous English novelist C. P. Snow while I was a student at the University of California. I asked Snow what he thought of Eliot as a dramatist. He remarked with acerbity that ''when the old party dies, his plays die with him.'' Thirty-one years later, with Eliot's plays making a comeback, it is, of course, Snow that no one reads anymore.
THOMAS S. KERRIGAN Sherman Oaks, Calif.
